author: A_Brickset_user
title: Very Collectable
review:
In my opinion, 918, the littlest of the three original LL 92x ships (along with 924 and 928, the first "LEGOLAND Space" themed spaceships) is without doubt one of the most collectable LEGO sets of all time.  For a lot of Space collectors, and LEGO collectors in general, it is the prized set of their collection, or at the top of the list of sets they would like to add to their collection.  As a collector of LEGO, I judge by a few factors what makes a set collectable - this set has several factors (besides desirability) which make it very collectable:

1 - Part of a "series" that is very popular (as a key set in the first wave of LEGOLAND Space theme sets, this set is collectable and sought after for that reason alone).

2 - Elusive parts.  Most sets consist of parts that are not unique, while some of the most desired and hardest to find (complete) sets contain unique parts which were only found in only one set ever... From the Castle theme, 6011 had a unique "grey" chest, 6023 had a unique "white" maiden's hat, 6067 had unique red walls and a unique flag, 6041 had a unique colored goblet and a unique colored sword).  This set has a unique "elusive dashboard" piece that was only released in this set and never in any other, to the best of my knowledge.  It is also the only set that contained blue 1x4 bricks with "LL918" printed on the side.

3 - Difficulty of finding a box.  For collectors looking for an entire collection including the wonderful boxes and their great art, the box from this set has proven to be one of the most difficult LEGOLAND boxes to find.  For those collecting MISB (mint in sealed box - unopened, new) sets, there just aren't enough of these in the world to go around, thus you can expect the price to be pretty crazy IF you manage to locate one.  Almost forgot to mention, finding a complete loose (unboxed) version of this set with genuine instructions (not scans or photocopies) is also very, very uncommon - so the instructions are quite rare, as well.

4 - Limited release.  This set was not sold in the United States.  LL918's sister ships LL924 (set #924) and LL928 (set #928) were offered in the United States as sets 487 (Space Cruiser) and 497 (Galaxy Explorer).  Of the 4 LEGOLAND Castle theme sets that I mentioned with unique pieces, 3 of those (6011, 6023, 6067) were also not offered in stores in the US (though they were sold, in very small numbers, through LEGO Shop at Home catalogs) and are therefore quite a bit more difficult, at least for US collectors, to find.

With all that said, this set has quite a few collectablity factors summed up as rarity, uniqueness of parts and limited availability.  The most important factor of course is desirability...

Modelwise, this set is very simple and very small.  Aside from the unique pieces, all of the pieces are "compatible" with the other LEGOLAND themes (of that time and today!), which I count as a plus, since LEGO, in my mind, is supposed to be unlimited in building possibilities.  Unfortunately, LEGO just is not that way anymore with so many theme-specific pieces being made for all the various themes.

The model looks good, like a small one-man space ship, and it doesn't break up upon re-entry like the grand "Galaxy Explorer" which falls apart easily.  While 928 (497) Galaxy Explorer is a flagship set, and is a truly great set in nearly every way, it is not nearly as rare or hard to find as 918, and doesn't have the uniqueness of parts, and in my humble opinion, is less realistic in appearance than 918.

For those (probably Americans) who "thought they had all the earliest Space sets" and then see this one, it will make a great addition to their already very nice collections.  If you just like "knowing you have them all" then this set is a good one to have, and if you like to display your models then 918 is certainly a great addition to the 924 and 928 display...

In 1999, I spent a couple days rebuilding all these classic sets and covered the dining room table and had just as much fun, I guess, as I did when I was 8 doing the same thing.  They really did look cool!  Unfortunately, I sold most of those sets, thinking I could re-acquire them later in life when finances are better (aye, to dream, and still dreaming haha) yet I didn't sell my boxed 918, as it had been extremely hard to find.  That doesn't seem to have changed.

For these reasons, this set is very desirable, in my opinion, for any Classic Space collector, self included, and, in conclusion, the rarity factors along with the desirability make this an extremely collectable set.  And the going price seems to substantiate my opinion.  Personally, I think it's the #1 space set in terms of collectability, followed closely by 1593.

One other thing... if you have one (or more!) of these available for sale/trade/(donation?!), please let me know!  I won't hold my breath!  Happy building/collecting/reminiscing!

author: A_Brickset_user
title: Wonderful
review: Just got this off ebay for (a steal).  Love it !  Simple yet advanced for the first of the best lego space ships.  6980 is the all time best, but the LL ships are great.  A must for every space Lego fan.

author: A_Brickset_user
title: A timeless classic
review:
I always wanted this set when I was a kid but it wasn't until recently that I finally acquired one.
To make up for this gap in my childhood fleet I built my own variation which was a better design (in my opinion!)
Now my own variant and the original can sit side by side!

This must be one of the easiest spacecraft to pilot ever, as it can be operated by just 5 knobs from a domestic cooker!!!! Other craft in the series needed computers and stuff to control them but little old LL918 would fly quite happily on Gas Mark 5!
For your travelling spaceman, luggage stowage is quite limited with only 2 small cargo doors, but what do you expect with the spacecraft version of the sporty coupe?
While the LL918 can rocket along in the vacuum of space without worry, atmospheric performance is hampered by poor aerodynamics below the wing-line.
Access to the cockpit is through the gullwing-style roof panel so boarding is slightly tricky for the shorter minifig.
Finally, the large single engine is more than enough to power such a small spacecraft, and cornering in those tricky asteroid fields is brought about by 2 sets of directional thrusters.
An excellent buy for any budding space entrepreneur or junior executive!

author: A_Brickset_user
title: Awesome Lego
review:
This is the set that I remember most vividly from my childhood.  The smaller one seat design made this little ship seem like it was much faster and much more manoeuvrable than the larger 924 and much larger 928.  

It holds a special spot in my collection as it was obviously the inspiration for the great Galaxy Explorer (set 928) which is still one of my favourite sets of all time.  It's also one of the more rare space lego sets. Finding one in good condition with original box and instructions will cost you lots. 

Great design.  Great ship.

author: A_Brickset_user
title: I have it
review:
Unfortunatley the box no longer exists, but I do have the LL918 along with the complete LL928.

Got the sets out of my parents attic a couple of weeks ago along with a good number of other classic vehicles and space buildings.

Its amazing to see there is still interest in what I would describe as the best Lego of all time.

author: Doctor_Sinister
title: Scramble fighters!
review:
When I had my moonbase, many years ago, this ship was assigned interceptor duties - you see, my moonbase was exclusively military in nature, which was a shame, as the men stationed there had no-one to fight.  But nevertheless, they had a good fighter with this set - and I often wished I had a second one, because you can never have too many fighters, especially ones that look this good.

Dr. S.

author: petro17sq
title: Gread small ship
review:
I own the Galaxy Explorer since I was I kid and know using Bricklink I found the bricks to build this one, actually I still have to buy 3 or 4 brick (The most expensive ones) but for me I consider that I own this set already, I am also buying the piece for the medium ship 924 and I hope to finish at the end of the year the 3 classic space ships.
The only problem then is that my Galaxy Explorer is in a box in my apartment back home in another continent!

author: isolator42
title: Should've won a Design Award...
review:
When the 11 Legoland Space sets first came out in the UK in 1979, I was 10 years old & thought I had gone to toy heaven. I used my pocket-money to buy as much of them as possible, & got all the smaller sets. The 4 biggest sets were beyond my means, so this was the biggest one I had.
It is perfectly proportioned and pleasing to the eye from every angle (like a well designed car) and has just the right amount of "extra bits" bristling off it - techy looking but not bristling with OTT fussy details. 
As I approach 40, I still like it as much as I did nearly 30 years ago...

author: Paul_Baulch
title: Perfection in a LEGO spaceship
review:
This spaceship sports the excellent Classic Space colour scheme, and has a visual design that is about as close to perfect as I can imagine for a LEGO spaceship.
For a start, it's visually balanced, having structure which extends about as far underneath the wing surface as it does above, unlike its larger cousins 924 and 928 which have am inferior "stuff plonked on top of the wing" look to them, or later sets which would feature spindly wings, struts or oversized tails or weapons.
Secondly, it displays a wonderful minimalism in that all the components are there to perform some reasonably obvious function, and are placed in aesthetically pleasing spots. Lastly, it's an incredibly efficient design, providing a compact assortment of internal features while maintaining a sleekness of exterior.

Perfection.

author: ra226
title: The Very Definition of Classic Space
review:
In 1979, when I was only a few years old, Lego released set #918 along with a select few other sets as part of the brand new Lego Space theme.  Along with Town and Castle, Space would define Lego for a generation of kids.  Alas, I was too young to acquire the "One Man Transport" (even the names were left to imagination back then!) as a child--though in this case it wouldn't have mattered as the 918 was never released in America.

Building this set evokes instant nostalgia, bringing you back to the Golden Age of Lego.  This simple ship, which has only a steering wheel and 5 knobs for flight control, whisks you back to a time before the Internet, when man had walked on the moon only 10 years prior.  The Cold War was still on, but Lego knew that someday soon the space man in White and the space man in Red would be working side by side to better our future.

Back then, Lego Space was about exploration, launching satellites, staying in communication (everyone had a walkie-talkie!), transporting cargo, and resupplying your various operations.  In short, it wasn't much different than actual space.  The 918 reflects this utilitarian mission: it has a large main engine, maneuvering thrusters, landing lights, a sealed cabin, and a small cargo compartment which might double as a sleeping compartment.  Unlike its bigger cousins, the 924 and 928, it comes with only a pilot--and no accessories.  For this reason, I imagine the 918 to be more of a light courier--perhaps meant to deliver small packages or maybe the occasional diplomat.

Like the other sets in the theme, the 918 has the signature blue and grey with trans-yellow color scheme that characterized most of early Classic Space.  Every part is useful, and some have remained quite rare over the years.  The ship is perfect in form and looks great beside the 924 and 928.  It is also highly swooshable--and would be even if it weren't a legend.

I'm very excited to finally own this set!  Having it represents an old dream finally come true.  Another reviewer described it as simply "timeless."  For me, the 918 isn't just a piece of Lego Classic Space--it's the definition of it.

author: one79
title: Space Ship, prepare for landing! (my imagination when I was a kid)
review:
Do you still remember LEGO® Space set? To those of you that remember it, you are our respected LEGO® veterans. The set 918 - One Man Space Ship is a set released on 1979 and coincidentally, the author is fortunate to be able to buy it along with several other vintage sets. Although this set is already 40 years old, we can still review it, right?

These set has four printed parts on it. The author is lucky to get this set with intact printed parts. Usually after 40 years have passed, the printed graphic will fade away. Unfortunately, the golden colour on the planet image located on the spaceman minifigure chest has faded. Now the author started to understand why some AFOL dislike stickers on LEGO sets. It seems in the past the LEGO Group printed images directly on the LEGO® parts.

Like what you can see on the photos below, even though this LEGO® Space set is very simple, but on his era, this set will trigger unlimited imaginations. This happens mainly to those of you that grew up with this set or at least know this set but could not get it (like me when I was a kid).

This LEGO® spaceship does not utilise wheels for taking off and landing. This spaceship hovers and vertically in air (or shall we say in space) vertically like harrier plane and depends on the thruster at the rear side to throttle forward. Like most airplane, it has lights and also equipped with antennae for long range communication.

This spaceship has storage section on the rear part of the fuselage on the left and right. The spaceship probably is bringing supply to a planetary base or colony on specific planet. The cockpit can be opened to one side for the convenience of the pilot to getting in or getting off the spaceship.

Besides the component with printed images and numbers, there are two rare parts on this set which are the front cockpit windshield and cockpit ceiling in trans yellow colour. The trans yellow cockpit windshield is only available on nine LEGO® sets. While, the 4 x 6 trans yellow plate is only available on two LEGO® sets which is on this set and on Blacktron 7687 set.

What do you think of this classic LEGO® space set? An amazing set, right? It looks so futuristic! And you will never thought that this simple set was designed 40 years ago.

Building Experience

It is fun to build this set. Especially if you were around when this set was released. It definitely have a strong nostalgic value.

Parts

As with all vintage sets, the part count is small.

Playability

You will definitely kept playing with it when you were a kids and let your imagination run wild. I know since I did.

Value For Money

I can only give this neutral since I bought it more than 40 years later as used set.

Special Note

I might be a bit biased since this is one of the set when I was a kid, but I try my best to be objective.

Please note that I write this review based on my own LEGO Blog article which is available from: https://indobrickville.com/main/lego-set-review-918-one-man-space-ship.

I hope this insight from me will be useful for all AFOLs out there!

author: bricksofcanada
title: 4 stars!
review:
the smallest of the variations of galaxy explorers, this little spaceship has what you'd expect of a classic space set from 1979. very minimal detail, lack of play features, and overall a blocky appearance. BUT, just because of the way it shows perfectly the true classic space feel, i am giving it 4 stars anyway.

(interesting features include:

cockpit raises up,

and some doors on the back that aren't very useful for storing anything)

 

a perfect addition to any classic space layout.
